abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Energy Access Project
            for Ethiopia were as follows: outcomes were moderately
            unsatisfactory, global environmental objective (GEO)
            outcomes were moderately unsatisfactory, risk to development
            outcome was substantial, risk to GEO outcome was moderate,
            Bank performance was moderately unsatisfactory, and Borrower
            performance was moderately unsatisfactory. Some lessons
            learned included: multi-sector energy project without a
            strong, cross-sector institutional focus can result in a
            loss of commitment and underachievement of objectives.
            Notwithstanding the need to address urgent issues in
            multiple energy subsectors, if project scope and design are
            not tailored to the institutional capacity of the
            implementing agencies, there is a substantial risk of delays
            and limited achievement of project objectives. The lack of
            performance indicators for capacity building and the absence
            of a clear linkage to planning for staff-development limit
            the extent of impact assessment for training and technical
            assistance programs. If the detailed design of a major
            project is not completed prior to credit approval for an
            investment operation, there is a high risk of delay and or
            cancellation. The lack of a clear results chain in a
            monitoring and evaluation (M and E) framework can lead to
            major data gaps and missed opportunities for impact
            evaluation. The lack of a system of standardized testing for
            improved fuel wood stoves prevents a full assessment of the
            program's impact on reducing emissions from the burning
            of wood. The lack of detailed coordination of rehabilitation
            work for urban power distribution systems with city planning
            authorities and shortages of local construction materials
            can be major obstacles to timely completion of the work.
